text: <@U1C8K9DH8|imchanst> has joined the channel
<@U14NC480K|charles-cai> has joined the channel
<@U0MS9352A|rehmke> has joined the channel

<@U0UL07VSL> <@U0ULQ2G5V>: There's a sentence in the overview of the Asset Depository use case's introduction that I want to ask about: "Transfer of fiat money in compensation for the transfer of assets lies outside of the distributed ledger's capability and is not covered by this use case. Whenever a transfer of ownership is approved by both parties to the trade it is assumed the seller has been compensated." - This seems to suggest that DLT can't do Delivery vs. Payment (DvP). Are we sure about that?
<@U14KZA474>: yes the clause ' approved by both parties to the trade' should be removed if we are to generalize it
I'll clean it up
<@U0ULQ2G5V> - I meant the first sentence - one of the use cases that Ram added is DvP - which would seem to be at odds with our sentence
what's the link to Ram's use case please?
<https://github.com/hyperledger/hyperledger/wiki/Use-Case-Post-Trade>

attachments.title: hyperledger/hyperledger
attachments.text: Hyperledger Project is a new Collaborative Project at The Linux Foundation. The technical community is just getting started and will be adding code to the repository in the coming weeks. Check hype...

text: easy way to handle this sort of thing might be to follow Frank's guidance of segregating use case from solution from pros/cons
in a sense, we simplify the use case away from the implications
agree. Need to rephrase that clause. Need also to discuss how we treat use cases where fiat money is involved.
<@U14KZA474>: DvP is so fundamental to asset depository use cases
there is another short paragraph description on AD use case posted in the whitepaper draft
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Z4M_qwILLRehPbVRUsJ3OF8Iir-gqS-ZYe7W-LE9gnE/pub>
I was planning to replace the description in the use case section with the version in the whitepaper, are you ok with it <@U0ULQ2G5V> ?
neither is quite right
assets don't have to be dematerialized for dlt to work as a book-entry ledger that records who owns what
replace dematerialzed? represented?
it's the paper record of the title to the asset that is dematerialized
<@U0UL07VSL>: ok with the white paper description
the white paper description also violates Frank's guidance about leaving aside the economic interests, no?
actually, for some reason google doc  didn't reflect to the latest changes we made to the document
let me find the "real" version
I'll work on the DvP use case and then we can discuss on Tuesday
we changed it too something like this :

Financial Asset depository
Assets such as financial securities must be able to be dematerialized on a blockchain network, so that all stakeholders of an asset type will have direct access to each asset, allowing them to initiate trades and acquire information on an asset without going through layers of intermediaries. Trades can be settled in a timeframe agreed between the stakeholders, including near real time if required, and all stakeholders must be able to access asset information in near real time. A stakeholder should be able to add business rules for any given asset type, which further reduces operating costs by implementing automation logic. The creator of the asset must be able to make the asset and any rules associated with the trading of that asset private and confidential, or public as the use case warrants. For example, the creator should be able to create an asset such that the trade history and current balance of a holder of the asset is not available to the other asset holders and perhaps not even available the the creator itself.
this is also based on a suggestion made by a community member _"Trades can be settled in a timeframe agreed between the stakeholders, including near real time if required, "_
this way we can artfully avoid the debate on the economic benefit/drawbacks of near realtime settlement
